author: vors
body:
<!--

If you are running a released version of powershell, but not the latest one, install the latest from https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases and try to repro it again

Before submitting this issue, please first:

- [ ] Search the existing issues.
- [ ] Refer to the [FAQ](../docs/FAQ.md).
- [ ] Refer to the [known issues](../docs/KNOWNISSUES.md).
- [ ] If it is a bug, fill out this form:
-->
## Steps to reproduce
- From windows box, open inbox powershell
- ssh to a linux VM. Use ssh that comes with windows version of git from command line

```
C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\ssh.exe
```
- Follow [instructions](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/building/linux.md#toolchain-setup) to install powershell
- Everything works fine up to this point
- Run powershell
- Try to do something
## Expected behavior

You should be able to work
## Actual behavior

Console UX is broken:
half of commands are entered at the top of the screen, overriding the buffer

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/816680/15945104/96e1e294-2e45-11e6-8f91-a2c59efa13e0.png)
## Environment data

<!-- If running the latest released version, specify the version, i.e. -->

v0.4.0

comments.author: vors
comments.body: Workaround: use `putty` as ssh client

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body: @vors: thanks

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body: This problem also affects PowerShell running within _Bash on Ubuntu on Windows_ whether directly in the bash console or in ConEmu. As soon as I start typing, the cursor moves to column 0 ...  and if the prompt past line 10, it goes back to line 0.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body: I'm experiencing this as well. Makes the linux experience nearly unusable. Putty is a pretty undesirable workaround.

comments.author: mwrock
comments.body: I typically use the mingw ssh that ships with git. Note that in SSH my `TERM` is set to `cygwin` I just thought I'd try `ssh` from the Bash on Ubuntu on Windows. This is a much better experience. A few little glitches but workable. `TERM` is set to `xterm` here.

comments.author: MathiasMagnus
comments.body:
Same here. I wanted to try PS on an Ubuntu 16.04 remote cluster node, but the console got really messed up. I tried both ssh.exe that ships with Git for Windows, and also the one from bash.exe (upgraded to Ubuntu 16.04). Neither worked properly. Arrow keys not working properly to move inline and in history, in some places backspace doesn't work... not glitched, but broken.

The few commands that worked got the expected results, so anticipation is not lost, but grew even more. Very eager to try a fixed version, or even start tweaking with a hotfix, but Putty really is not an elegant workaround.

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body: By the way guys, if you install PowerShell core on your windows box, you can use PowerShell remoting to the Ubuntu box (over SSH). That seems to be working fine (with the exception that _at least with ConEmu in the way_, the Ctrl+C/Ctrl+V don't work in PSReadLine).

comments.author: MathiasMagnus
comments.body:
I found [this](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/tree/master/demos/SSHRemoting) tutorial on PowerShell Core and SSH remoting, but it does not work, at all. The installed PS Core 6.0.0.9 fails to ping not just the host, but even itself.

Microsoft PowerShell:

```
PS C:\Users\Matty> Test-Connection 127.0.0.1

Source        Destination     IPV4Address      IPV6Address                              Bytes    Time(ms)
------        -----------     -----------      -----------                              -----    --------
MATTY-Z50-75  127.0.0.1       148.6.182.187    ::1                                      32       0
MATTY-Z50-75  127.0.0.1       148.6.182.187    ::1                                      32       0
MATTY-Z50-75  127.0.0.1       148.6.182.187    ::1                                      32       0
MATTY-Z50-75  127.0.0.1       148.6.182.187    ::1                                      32       0
```

PowerShell Core:

```
PS C:\Kellekek\Microsoft\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> Test-Connection 127.0.0.1
Test-Connection : Az ügyfél nem tud kapcsolatot létesíteni a kérelemben megadott célhellyel.  Ellenőrizze, hogy a célhelyen a szolgáltatás fut és kész kérések fogadására. Tekintse meg a célhelyen futó WS-Management szolgáltatás (általáb
an az IIS vagy a Rendszerfelügyeleti webszolgáltatások) naplóját és dokumentációját. Ha a célhely a Rendszerfelügyeleti webszolgáltatás, a következő parancs azon történő futtatásával elemezheti és konfigurálhatja a Rendszerfelügyeleti w
ebszolgáltatásokat: "winrm quickconfig".
At line:1 char:1
+ Test-Connection 127.0.0.1
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (:) [Test-Connection], CimException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : TestConnectionException,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.TestConnectionCommand
```

(Translation: the client cannot establish a connection with the required remote client...) Am I doing something wrong? New-PSSession says:

```
PS C:\Kellekek\Microsoft\PowerShell\6.0.0.9> $session = New-PSSession -HostName ...
New-PSSession : [<hostname here>] An error has occurred which Windows PowerShell cannot handle. A remote session might have ended.
At line:1 char:12
+ $session = New-PSSession -HostName <hostname here> -UserName ...
+            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : OpenError: (System.Manageme....RemoteRunspace:RemoteRunspace) [New-PSSession], PSRemotingDataStructureException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : PSSessionOpenFailed
```

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body: This issue was moved to lzybkr/PSReadLine#471

comments.author: Jaykul
comments.body:
@joeyaiello @lzybkr  is this really "OK"?
I mean -- how can PowerShell close this?

I mean, I'm uncomfortable with taking a mandatory dependency on an _external_ module for the REPL prompt in the first place -- is there **any** functionality more core to the purpose of a **shell** than this?

But if it's broken in a way that impacts docker connections, and PowerShell in WSL, that seems beyond an _unfortunate_ bug in an external module, and into core functionality.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: This might not be PSReadline.  I can repro with the original steps and after some trial and error was able to remove PSReadline and it still had an issue.  I'll investigate this.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body:
I tried this with alpha.18 and had the same problem.  However, trying it with latest master and setting TERM=xterm it appears to work fine with win32 port of ssh.exe from our other GitHub repo (not the one that comes with Git).

At this point, it may just be a documentation issue.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: Issue from Win32-OpenSSH to on TERM not being set https://github.com/PowerShell/Win32-OpenSSH/issues/252

comments.author: KirkMunro
comments.body: I don't think it's quite as simple as setting TERM=xterm. I'm hitting this issue with an environment that uses Shell in a Box. I've configured my Shell in a Box web server such that the.ip.address/ps will invoke docker run -e TERM=xterm -it microsoft/powershell, and in the docker session I connect to in the browser where TERM is set to xterm the issue still persists. Yet other endpoints I create (such as one for ssh) work just fine.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @KirkMunro I'll setup ShellInABox and will investigate this further

comments.author: KirkMunro
comments.body: Great, thanks. @SteveL-MSFT, if you have questions about ShellInABox, let me know.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @KirkMunro got a repro.  ShellInABox is pretty cool i have to say, we definitely want powershell working in this environment

comments.author: KirkMunro
comments.body: @SteveL-MSFT Glad you got the repro going. ShellInABox is really cool. I have a modified fork of it (https://github.com/KirkMunro/shellinabox) right now that supports launching PowerShell in a docker container via a POSH endpoint, or for user-defined ssh/mosh targets. I'd like to plug PSRemoting in there as well once I have more time.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @KirkMunro can you open a separate issue for ShellInABox?  I believe this original issue is something OpenSSH needs to address.  Thanks

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
@MaximoTrinidad yeah, Ctrl+C doesn't work for me either. Only Ctrl+Break to leave the session entirely.

That being said, @bagajjal isn't getting a repro on his Win 10 CU box at all, so we're digging in to see what the difference is between our two machines. Given that PuTTY works fine for both of us, we think this is in the OpenSSH layer, so I opened an issue at PowerShell/Win32-OpenSSH#733.

title: Running PowerShell Core under SSH from Windows results in broken UX
